docs.summary: An element for working with paging.
description: A pagination bar provides a way for your users to control the [paging of
a dataset](wix-dataset/introduction#dataset-pages). Elements that are connected to the
same dataset as the pagination bar are affected when the user
interacts with the pagination bar.
For example, suppose you have a repeater connected to a dataset and that dataset
is set to have a page size of 5. When the page loads, the repeater shows
the first 5 items from the dataset. If a user clicks on the next page button
of a pagination bar connected to the same dataset as the repeater,
the repeater then shows items 6-10 from the dataset.
You can also use a pagination bar without connecting it to a dataset.
When doing so, you have to provide the pagination logic that runs when
a user interacts with the pagination bar.

docs.summary: Sets or gets the current page.
description: Setting the `currentPage` property updates the visual indicator of the
pagination bar to display the current page. The `currentPage` cannot be
set to a value greater than [`totalPages`](#totalPages).
If the pagination bar is connected to a dataset, setting `currentPage`
updates the current page of the dataset and updates any relevant
elements connected to that dataset.
Getting the `currentPage` property returns the index of the current page.
> **Note:**
> * Page numbers begin with 1.
> * When [`navigationType`](#navigationType) is set to `arrowsOnly`, the `currentPage` property returns `undefined`.

examples.title: Get a pagination bar's current page
Set a pagination bar's current page

docs.summary: Sets or gets the navigation layout displayed in the pagination bar.
description: There are 3 types of navigation layouts:
+ `clickNumbers`: Displays the page numbers as clickable links.
![](../assets/images/pagination-clickNumbers.png)
+ `inputNumbers`: Allows the site visitor to input a desired page number.
![](../assets/images/pagination-inputNumbers.png)
+ `arrowsOnly`: Hides the page numbers so that only the next and previous buttons are displayed.
![](../assets/images/pagination-arrowsOnly.png)
>**Note:**
>When `navigationType` is set to `arrowsOnly`, the pagination bar's `currentPage` and `totalPages` properties return `undefined`.

examples.title: Get a pagination bar's current navigation layout
Set a pagination bar's navigation layout

docs.summary: Sets or gets whether the pagination bar's next page button is enabled.
description: If you don't set `nextEnabled` in your code, the next page button follows the pagination bar's default behavior.
This means the button is disabled when the final page of data is displayed, and enabled otherwise.
>**Note**:
>Once you set the value of `nextEnabled` in your code, the next page button stops following the pagination bar's defaults.
>Make sure to disable the next button in your code when the final page of data is displayed.

examples.title: Check if a pagination bar's next page button is enabled
Set the status of a pagination bar's next page button
Restrict some pages to members with a specific paid plan
body: // Set an event handler to run every time the pagination bar's page changes.
// If the current page is 1-3 make sure the next button is enabled
// For pages between 4 and the last page, first disable the next button.
// Use the getCurrentMemberOrders() function to retrieve all the plans the current memeber is subcribed to.
// If the current member has an active premium account, enable the next button.
// If the current page is the last page, disable the next button.

extra.description:
This example implements custom logic for when a pagination bar's next button is enabled:
 * Pages 1-3: The next button is enabled.
 * Pages 4 and up: The code uses the Wix Paid Plans API to check if the current member has an active 'Premium' plan subscription. 
   If they don't, the next button is disabled and the following pages can't be accessed.
 * The last page: The next button is disabled manually in the code.

docs.summary: Sets or gets whether the pagination bar's previous page button is enabled.
description: If you don't set `previousEnabled` in your code, the previous page button follows the pagination bar's default behavior.
This means the button is disabled when the first page of data is displayed, and enabled otherwise.
>**Note**:
>Once you set the value of `previousEnabled` in your code the previous page button stops following the pagination bar's defaults.
>Make sure to disable the previous button in your code when the first page of data is displayed.

examples.title: Check if a pagination bar's previous page button is enabled
Set the status of a pagination bar's previous page button

docs.summary: Sets or gets the total number of pages shown in a pagination bar.
description: Setting the `totalPages` property updates the number of pages shown in
the pagination bar.
Setting `totalPages` to a value less than [`currentPage`](#currentPage)
causes `currentPage` to be reset to the new `totalPages` value. For
example, if `currentPage` is `8` and `totalPages` is set to `5`, `currentPage`
is reset automatically to `5`.
If the pagination bar is connected to a dataset, it is recommended that
you allow the dateset to control the pagination bar's `totalPages` value.
Getting the `totalPages` property returns the total number of pages available
for selection in the pagination bar. If the pagination bar is
connected to a dataset, the initial `totalPages` value is calculated based
on the total number of items in the dataset and the dataset's page size.
>**Note:**
>When [`navigationType`](#navigationType) is set to `arrowsOnly`, the `totalPages` property returns `undefined`.

examples.title: Get the number of pages available in a pagination element
Set the number of pages available in a pagination element

params.name: handler
params.doc:
The name of the function or
 the function expression to run when the item is ready.

ret.doc: The pagination bar on which the event is now registered.

docs.summary:
Adds an event handler that runs when the pagination bar
 is changed.
description: A pagination bar receives a `change` event when a user changes the
current page by interacting with the pagination bar.
A `change` event is not triggered when you change a pagination bar's
current page using the [`currentPage`](#currentPage) property.
When a pagination bar is connected to a dataset, changing the [dataset's
current page](wix-dataset/introduction#wix-dataset_introduction_dataset-pages) using dataset functions, such
as [`nextPage()`](wix-dataset.Dataset.html#nextPage), doesn't trigger `change`
events on the pagination bar.

examples.title: Get the new current page of the pagination bar that was changed

params.name: handler
params.doc:
The name of the function or
 the function expression to run when the next page button is clicked.

ret.doc: The pagination bar on which the event is now registered.

docs.summary: Adds an event handler that runs when the pagination bar's next page button is clicked.
description: The `onNextClicked()` event runs before the pagination bar's [`onChange()`](#onChange) event and before its [`currentPage`](#currentPage) property is updated.

examples.title: Set a pagination bar's onNextClicked event handler

params.name: handler
params.doc:
The name of the function or
 the function expression to run when the previous page button is clicked.

ret.doc: The pagination bar on which the event is now registered.

docs.summary: Adds an event handler that runs when the pagination bar's previous page button is clicked.
description: The `onPreviousClicked()` event gets triggered before the pagination bar's [`onChange()`](#onChange) event and before its [`currentPage`](#currentPage) property is updated.

examples.title: Set a pagination bar's onPreviousClicked event handler
